title: Pumpkin Spice at a Deadly Price (Brambleberry Bay Murder Club Book 7)
author: Addison Moore
blurb_text: This Book Club just turned into a Murder Club. In Brambleberry Bay, pumpkin spice comes with a body count. Fall’s favorite flavor just turned fatal, and this Thanksgiving, secrets are the main ingredient. It’s autumn in Brambleberry Bay and the leaves are falling and the air is crisp. The whole town is gearing up for our annual Pumpkin Spice Festival with festive treats, cozy sweaters, rides, games, and a touch of small-town charm. It’s the perfect time to relax, and snuggle with my boyfriend and talking pets—until someone drops dead at my feet. I just can’t catch a break.  It’s so cozy it’s criminal! *RECIPE INCLUDED*  There’s nothing like a cozy fall festival, crisp autumn air, and a steaming cup of pumpkin spice latte—unless you’re sipping it while someone drops dead in the middle of the Pumpkin Palooza.  Hi, I’m Hattie Holiday. Mind reader, animal whisperer, and unofficial ringleader of Brambleberry Bay’s most eccentric murder club. When the beloved owner of Spice It Up Café keels over just before being crowned Pumpkin Queen, I smell something foul—and it’s not just the cinnamon overload in her award-winning pie.  Was it the bitter baker she beat out for the crown? The café rival whose recipe she may have stolen? Or the shady head judge with a messy past and a suspiciously close connection to the victim?  Between decoding deadly desserts and trying to figure out if my hot detective boyfriend is secretly rekindling things with his ex, it’s a miracle I haven’t been poisoned by pumpkin myself. But with my wily crew and furry sidekicks by my side, we’ll sift through suspects faster than you can say “maple-glazed murder.”  One thing is for sure—this fall, someone is baking up more than just trouble. And I intend to serve justice with a side of whipped cream.  A mind reader. Talking pets. An arrogant homicide detective. A murder club. And a corpse.  Welcome to the club. Getting in was easy. Getting out can be murder.  Living in Brambleberry Bay can be a real killer.  It’s criminally cozy. Meanwhile, Wiggins, Jury’s partner at New Scotland Yard, becomes sidetracked by an investigation of his own: His sister, missing for years and presumed dead, has just sent a postcard to their mother. Funny, eccentric, and fueled by Richard Jury’s talent for seeing clues in the most unlikely places, The Red Queen is a welcome return to a classic character and an exciting addition to a series that has been called “delightful, surprising, even magical” (Washington Post).

Nestled in the heart of rural Oldshire, the cathedral city of Oldminster is all ivy-covered colleges, creaking bookshops, and genteel façades. But don’t be fooled by the charm — beneath the cobbled streets and tidy hedgerows lies a world of intrigue. From ancient family estates like Renfield Hall to the atmospheric lanes of Abbot’s Grayling, this is a place where aristocratic pride clashes with modern ambition, and murder is never far from the tea tray. Because in Oldminster, everyone has something to hide — and someone is always watching. Perfect for fans of Midsomer Murders, M.C. Beaton, Faith Martin, Simon Brett, Dorothy L. MEET YOUR DETECTIVES Inspector Paul French has always been a stickler for order — until the arrival of his baby daughter late in his marriage to Moira turned his orderly world upside down. Always impeccably polite — he knows how to navigate aristocratic pretensions, local feuds, and the labyrinthine ties of old village families, all without ruffling too many feathers. French is the kind of man who drinks strong tea, keeps a dog-eared notebook, and believes very firmly that murder, no matter how genteel its setting, must be treated with absolute seriousness. Thirty-something Sergeant Glyn Edwards is weathered from years of police work, with a dry humour that’s a hit among Oldminster’s tight-lipped locals. He lives with his wife Sandra, but his home life is anything but blissful. With his marriage slowly derailing, all he has to fall back on is his work. Together, French and Edwards unravel the most tangled of crimes proving that murder cannot hide . . . even in the prettiest villages.
